title: Thursday, 29th June, 2017

11:10 am
BE11:10am

This is on the not unexpected news that banks have too much money.

BE11:11am

US stress test beyond benign so, here, have some of their capital. Sure, we're not even a decade since the GFC but whatever.

BE11:11am

(@ROTR: read that Miles article above. It's good on whether valuations are crazy or not.)

11:11 am
BE11:11am

For HSBC specifically ...........

PM11:12am

Are Morgan Stanley saying HSBC will have $45bn of too much capital?

BE11:12am

I think that's pretty much consensus.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

sheesh

BE11:12am

Let me swing back to an overview on the capital plan first though.

BE11:13am

This, via Credit Suisse.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Bottom line: another step forward—all of our banks passed and were approved for materially higher payouts—several greater than 100% (gross and net) and in most cases, at levels in excess of our published expectations, at 100% gross and 88% net, median basis (we had forecast 85% net up from 70% in CCAR 2016) for the CS Large Cap Banks.

BE11:15am

PM11:15am

Blimey

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Dividend payout rates increased more materially, to 30% for the Large Cap Banks. The median 2017 CCAR period dividend payout ratio is estimated (based on CS forecast earnings) at 30% for the CS Large Cap Banks. This compares to our 27% estimate and a dividend payout rate of 28% in CCAR 2016. While capital return remains biased in favor of share repurchase, the increase in dividends was healthy, with CCAR 2017 approved annualized dividends set to increase 26% year to year, on a median basis. Noteworthy is the fact that more than half of our banks—STI, WFC, PNC, NTRS, USB, CFG and JPM have crossed the 30% threshold.
■ Highest total net capital payouts… in the CS Large Cap Bank group, Citigroup, JPMorgan, SunTrust, Citizens were approved for total net capital payouts equal to or in excess of 100%, based on Credit Suisse Research forecast earnings. Higher than expected payouts… each of the banks at 100%+ (C, JPM, STI, CFG) was approved for a net capital payout at least 15% above our forecast. Lower than expected payouts… U.S. Bancorp and Northern Trust came in the most materially below our forecast, with Northern Trust being the most disappointing, given its capital ratios and implied capacity.

BE11:17am

And UBS on what this means for HSBC individually.

BE11:17am

HSBC's [...] 4% gap between the DFAST CET1 ratio of 12.9% and the CCAR equivalent ratio of 8.9% applied to the firm's US$142bn US risk-weighted asset base implies US$5.7bn in capital planned for release from the US subsidiary, 3.2% of the group market cap. But before we assume a straight release of this capital to shareholders, we note three things: i) The US$5.7bn includes US$2.5bn already upstreamed to Group in 2017 to date; ii) the CCAR capital plan runs to 1Q19 – the further payments will be made over time, and iii) HSBC has to manage capital levels in a number of entities, including the European firm which has lower ratios than the US and Asian equivalents: not all of HSBC's capital buckets are full, not all capital upstreamed from subsidiaries is directed to shareholder payouts.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

…but not necessarily telling us much we didn't already know
Still, as highlighted in our "The risks of running a significant HSBC underweight have increased …" piece in May, HSBC's significantly better-than-forecast capital generation over the past 12 months, taking 1Q17 CET1 to 14.3%, should lead to greater confidence around capital returns. We moved then to assume a US$4bn buyback programme in each of 2H17 and FY18, the assumption of a flat dividend in 2018 (from a forecast cut under new management before), and the elimination of the scrip option in 2019. These forecasts were not contingent on the CCAR result – and so our view is unchanged today. We think HSBC offers attractive income and diversification – particularly for investors wary of UK domestic banking exposure in a pre-Brexit world – but trading at 1.3x TNAV for a forecast ROTE of 10% and with a running yield of 4-5%, compared with Lloyds Banking Group at 8.3%, we think these virtues are fairly valued and remain with a Neutral rating.

BE11:18am

As to Morgan Stanley .....

BE11:18am

......... fairly sure they published this pre stress test results.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Which I guess shows how low risk an event the test was considered.

BE11:19am

Anyway, the gist is similar. Too much money.

BE11:19am

And better that it goes back to shareholders than is lent out to folk who want to use it in the pursuit of economic growth etc.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

We expect the narrative on HSBC to flip from prior concerns
on the dividend to a debate on how to deploy excess capital.
We see actions to control RWAs as an underappreciated driver
of capital build and see room for a 20% cash yield over the
next three years – upgrade to Overweight

BE11:20am

1) Capital return to rise up the agenda – we model c.$45bn/500bps surplus by 2019 (pre-distribution). Our work suggests HSBC will be in the top quartile of EU banks for cash returns over the next three years. We expect capital to build to a 18.3% CET1 ratio pre-distribution by 2019 as gross RWA reduction of $50bn+ in GB&M/legacy should keep group RWA growth to c.1% a year and the drag from conduct/restructuring charges should fade. We factor in $33bn of dividends/buybacks (net scrip) and still see a surplus of $14bn by Dec 2019.

BE11:20am

2) Hong Kong net interest income to ratchet higher. HSBC is sitting on an underutilised balance sheet in HK with a loan-to-deposit ratio of c.50%, which will benefit as interest rates go up, and we note loan demand is also picking up sharply. We model 9% revenue CAGR in HK in the next three years

11:20 am
PM11:20am

If you explained what's happening here to the average joe on the street, I think the result would be rage.

BE11:21am

That says something about average Joe on the street as well, to be fair.

BE11:21am

3) UK fears overplayed with returns to remain robust. HSBC still has c.30% of its loan book in the UK ($264bn) and investors are cautious on the UK outlook given uncertainty over Brexit, politics and a squeeze on the consumer from rising inflation. We are more optimistic due to the high quality of the book and we think unemployment will remain low.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

We upgrade to Overweight and raise our price target by 14% to 850p, factoring in the capital surplus, higher earnings per share and 10% COE. We raise 2019e EPS by 8% on higher HK NIM, lower UK impairments driving PBT +4% and lower share count as we increase buybacks.

BE11:22am

Where could we be wrong? We do see risk to our call if rate hikes are delayed, protectionism impacts global trade / Asian macro outlook, if Brexit plays out badly, if regulations are tougher or if better Eurozone reflation leads to other European bank stocks outperforming.

Just looking at this risk/reward snapshot thing from MS....

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Are we about to get the Sky news?

BE11:26am

11:30 scheduled.

PM11:27am

What's your call?

11:26 am
BE11:27am

My money's on a CMA referral.

BE11:27am

Straight block looks wildly improbable.

BE11:28am

Straight approval looks politically risky, though the current government doesn't seem to be terribly good at politics so who knows.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

hehehe

BE11:28am

Here's a preview from RBC.

BE11:29am

Outcome #1 - Deal waved through, shares outperform: The first possibility is that the Secretary will assign limited risk to the public and wave the deal through. This would imply that Ofcom's concerns are relatively benign. Such an event is likely to provide a boost as it materially increases the deal's probability and reinforces a timeline for closure in CY17. However, this could create political risk for the government on objections to giving the Murdochs control of Sky.

Outcome #2 – Deal approved with concessions: The second outcome is that the Secretary and Fox have agreed to an “undertaking in lieu of a referral”, meaning the parties have reached certain concessions in the nine days since Ofcom provided its report to the DCMS. We believe the ruling Conservative Party is friendlier to the deal, but the recent election has moved them from the majority party to a minority party. FOXA has publicly said it is willing to make concessions. We think a couple of potential concessions that would likely have minimal impact on the financials of the deal could include greater corporate oversight and some form of editorial independence for Sky News. A more drastic concession could include spinning off Sky News, which we think FOXA would like to avoid. However, we’d note that in the previous merger attempt between FOXA and Sky in 2010 (then NWSA and BSkyB), FOXA did agree to spin out Sky News so we don’t see this as a complete dealbreaker. And, with the spin of the UK newspapers business as part of the FOXA/NWSA split, we would suspect the case to require the spinout is less compelling today. The risk here is that the government wants to avoid political blowback and not approve the deal (similar to Outcome #1). We see Outcome #2 as positive for FOXA shares as long as concession aren’t overly onerous.

Outcome #3 - Kick the can to the CMA: The third outcome could be the government kicking the deal to the Competition Markets Authority (CMA) for review. This would imply that either Ofcom has raised serious issues, or political pressures are significant to the point of the Conservatives not wanting to be the decider. This could insulate the government against accusations that it is in “collusion” with the Murdochs as they won't be forced to make any decision until the CMA reports back to the DCMS in ~6 months. In this event, the CMA would undertake a review of the deal and recommend approval, rejection or “suggested remedies”. While not a deal killer, we think this would cut the deal's probability to 50/50. Assuming around $2-$3/sh of our estimated $4/sh of accretion is in FOXA, implies around 5% downside on Outcome #3. We'd expect plenty of buyers on a 5% move and see this as an overreaction, hence we think this is the full downside cap.

Outcome #4 – The deal is shot down: In this scenario, DCMS would block the deal. We think this is very unlikely as if the DCMS wanted to block the deal, it would likely, in our view, refer the deal to the CMA for a full investigation first. In this scenario, we could see downside equal to the full $4 equity accretion adjusted for the probability that the deal doesn’t go through currently baked into the stock price.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Anyway, we'll be watching the tape for that.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 965.00, up 8.5 (+0.89%), High: 970.50, Low: 956.50, Volume: 1.09m

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Micro Focus mentioned on the right.

BE11:31am

This is Credit Suisse, I believe, sticking out some counterpoints to counterpoints to its recent sell note.

BE11:31am

The most common feedback was that adding
20pps of margin to HPE Software must represent an "opportunity". We argue that it's only an opportunity if it's unexpected. In contrast, we expect consensus forecasts to fully reflect the 20pps on day 1 of the transaction. As this consensus becomes visible, we think it will remove the hope of upgrades and make Micro Focus a story of execution against a high hurdle. This will bring the fundamental valuation more into focus, where Micro Focus looks expensive vs US peers. We reiterate our 1922p TP and Underperform rating while making some minor adjustments to our numbers.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Scan back on the archive for full details of their argument, the gist of which was that Cobol retirement rates are accelerating.

PM11:32am

ok...

BE11:32am

And that's a proxy for all vintage tech getting retired as everyone wants to be Uber, or whatever.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

They're also a little unkind about Micro Focus being a rollup.

PM11:33am

(Shame some of the vintage tech at my fingertips not being retired)

BE11:33am

Core shareholders in Micro Focus argue that we undervalue the ability of an M&A vehicle to create value. However, there is a difference between successful M&A companies and Micro Focus in terms of cash generation. Examples given to us typically convert 100% of profits into cash, while the figure is closer to 75% at Micro Focus. M&A vehicles also need M&A. After HPE Software, we think there are a limited number of targets that could make a difference to the enlarged group. And reported possible deals like BMC and CA (Reuters, 21 June) would merely reduce the number of potential targets

11:33 am
BE11:33am

So that's that.

Goldman's M&A basket.

"In the Consumer Products space, following the abandoned approach from Kraft Heinz, our analysts have updated the rank for Unilever to 2 (from 3)."

BE11:36am

and ...

BE11:36am

"In the Retail space, Luxottica announced an agreement to merge with Essilor in an all-share transaction [...]. While our analysts take no view on the proposed merger, the announcement increases the M&A rank for Luxottica to 1 from 3."

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Just to explain, there are three ranks in GS's system. A rank of 3 implies a less than 15% probability. Rank of 1 is 30%-50% probability. 2 is between those.

PM11:36am

Startling indeed

BE11:37am

The trigger to move from rank 3 to rank 2 appears being actually bid for.

11:01 am

We should say happy birthday to the iphone

Hammerson PLC (HMSO:LSE): Last: 579.50, up 1.5 (+0.26%), High: 583.50, Low: 578.50, Volume: 683.64k

Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,540, up 10 (+0.28%), High: 3,549, Low: 3,531, Volume: 238.25k
11:41 am
PM11:41am

(You wouldn't have put Unilever on an M&A list before you discovered it was being bid for...)

PM11:42am

What's the reheated story with Imps?

BE11:42am

(Several brokers did. Northern Trust for one.)

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Investec pushing this morning.

BE11:43am

Part of a sector thing ..........

BE11:43am

Consumer Staples have outperformed the broader market in 9 of the last 12 years, despite conditions routinely termed “challenging” by CEOs. But the sector is still close to its long-term 32% average PE premium to the market, given better-than-average earnings revisions over time. An absolute 21x PE for CY18E is elevated, but there are still plenty of tailwinds. Key Buys: Imperial Brands, Heineken. Key Sells: Reckitt Benckiser, Carlsberg.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Skipping to the inevitable .....

BE11:43am

Following significant M&A over the last 2 years, the companies are on average 2.2x net debt/EBITDA geared; only Nestlé, Unilever, L’Oréal, Henkel and Heineken can make a $10bn acquisition from internal resources currently, assuming net debt/EBITDA were taken temporarily to 4.0x. We nevertheless expect further substantial M&A, especially after the Kraft Heinz approach for Unilever. As targets, Danone and Imperial Tobacco are on our radar.

BE11:44am

(@alewis2005: ? "to 1 from 3" doesn't it say?)

11:44 am
BE11:44am

We resume coverage across 17 large cap stocks. Broadly, we consider Heineken, Nestlé and Campari as progressive companies with reasonable valuations. Danone and Imperial Brands as companies with well-understood issues, but where valuation is attractive and a takeover possible. We see short term earnings risk at Carlsberg, Diageo, Pernod, Reckitt and Tate. Visibility is currently limited at ABI and Unilever, where we stay on the sidelines for now. The remainder are at, or below, fair value with no clear catalyst at present, in our view, despite many having strong growth models (BAT and L’Oreal, for example).

British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 5,326, down 25 (-0.47%), High: 5,371, Low: 5,326, Volume: 535.63k
undefined
11:45 am
BE11:46am

Scanning requests briefly .............

BE11:46am

Someone was after DS Smith.

BE11:47am

Which has pressed the button on the big US acquisition it's always threatened.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

80% of Interstate Resources for £722m cash plus £177m debt.

BE11:47am

Which is a bit expensive.

BE11:48am

But strategically sensible, apparently.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Goodbody incoming.

BE11:48am

Interstate reported EBITDA of £50m in FY16 (£64m in FY15) pointing to a toppy initial EV/EBITDA multiple albeit in line with recent M&A in the region. DS Smith expects to generate £20m of synergies by end FY21 which will come at a one off cash cost of £45m while £75m of working capital is expected to be stripped out of the business. Overall, a post synergy EV/EBITDA multiple based on the assumption the business can recover to the operational performance of FY15 will be above 10x. We estimate that net debt/EBITDA in FY18 will be c.2.4x. We estimate negligible eps accretion in FY18 and by FY20/21 mid-single digits accretion. Interstate produces c. 430k tonnes of containerboard board and c. 240k tonnes of corrugated which leaves scope for corrugated bolt on’s as the business integrates. Although DS Smith has gained entry into a structurally more attractive market in the US relative to Europe it is not without its risks given the consideration. This will put increased importance on being able to bolt-on further businesses in a relatively short time span to leverage off the new assets and drive attractive returns to shareholders.

BE11:49am

And UBS.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

According to DS Smith, IRI had 2016 sales of $618m, pre-exceptional EBIT of £64m – equating to a multiple of 21.5x EBIT. Synergies of $25m by 2021 (DS Smith estimate) would see the post synergy multiple fall to 15.5x, and DS Smith indicated improved Y/Y trading at IRI in 2017. Based on 2015 results (EBIT at $82m), the multiple would be 17x EBIT pre-synergies, 13x post. DS Smith expects the acquisition to be EPS accretive immediately and achieve a ROCE above the DS Smith WACC in year 1. We expect low-single-digit EPS accretion initially. Assuming the 2015 EBIT and synergy deliveries would suggest EPS accretion by 2021 of c7-10%. As per the announcement, the remaining 20% of the business is to be acquired within 5 years unless otherwise agreed by buyer and seller (at a fixed multiple of 8x EBITDA).

BE11:49am

: A US acquisition has been long discussed by DS Smith, so we would expect this to be seen as a positive step. The post synergy acquisition multiple is 10-20% premium to the DS Smith multiple, so it is not a cheap acquisition; but overall we expect it to be well received as a positive strategic step

JD Sports Fashion PLC (JD.:LSE): Last: 369.75, down 28.05 (-7.05%), High: 388.00, Low: 350.70, Volume: 2.35m
BE11:52am

Looked briefly, figured it was just disappointment at an in-line update.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

On this AGM statement

PM11:52am

It's pretty muddled, no?

PM11:52am

"Since we reported our results for the last financial year, we have moved into a further period of year on year calendar differences, notably Eid, which has also led us to adjust the timing of our clearance period. Therefore, we do not believe our like for like store sales comparatives will be truly meaningful until the end of the first half, by which point the impact of the aforementioned timing differences and the strong comparatives from the performance through last year's Euros tournament will all have fully unwound. Nevertheless, we are pleased to confirm that growth to date in Group like for like store sales and further significant growth in the Group's online sales have been in line with our expectations.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

JD usually beats, at least in recent years, possibly because Sports Direct's shopping experience became "badly stocked general store in provincial Soviet Russia".

BE11:53am

Don't think the margin pressure stuff is a particular surprise.

BE11:54am

But it's priced to beat, and hasn't.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Have Peel Hunt, who remain buyers.

BE11:54am

Most retailers would die for JD's LFL but this time it's too early
in the year to upgrade. The equity story is evolving anyway: UK
store excellence will doubtless persist but the overseas expansion
plan is accelerating and new territories will be added, and
meanwhile the online growth remains eye-catching. Finally
expectations have mostly caught up with reality, but the fact that
forecasts have precisely doubled in the last two years, an
extraordinary run, made that certain to happen at some stage
anyway. It absolutely should not detract from the exciting
growth profile here, which is undervalued on 16x PE.

PM11:54am

Ameet Patel at Northern Trust is a seller

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Go on.

PM11:55am

For the past few updates/results JD Sports’s phenomenal performance has typically been at the top end, or well above, expectations. At FY16 results in April for example, PBT was 6% ahead of the highest estimate; at the mid-year trading update this time last year, the management guided towards the top end of the range. So is today’s trading update pointing towards FY being “in line with expectations” enough to buy the recent dip? We’re not convinced. Particularly given some other comments in the release which we think lack clarity or don’t read too well. First is the statement that “we do not believe our like for like store sales comparatives will be truly meaningful until the end of the first half”, attributed to the timing of calendar events – Euro championships last year and Eid this year – i.e. things that should have been known in advance. Second is the comment re “anticipated margin pressures” – known, but a reminder of the current earnings headwinds.

PM11:55am

Don’t get us wrong – we think JD Sports is a high quality business. But to us that feels priced in now, as do high expectations (still at a 22% premium to the FTSE 100 on F12M consensus P/E, which feels rich for a domestic retailer). And the clothing/footwear apparel space for traditional retailers continues to face rapid changes, not least the potential threat from Amazon’s Prime Wardrobe service which is likely still fresh in people’s minds.

11:55 am
PM11:56am

So he's not inclined to buy the dip

BE11:59am

BE11:59am

Citi's a buyer, if you want some of that.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Citi's Take — Purplebricks delivered a strong FY17 result with Group revenues of £46.7m and Adjusted EBITDA loss £-4.5m. Maiden revenue guidance of £80m in
the UK and £12m in Australia is +21% ahead of consensus on a total revenue basis. This is largely driven off the increased marketing investment of +£3.5m in
1H18e in the UK and capitalizes on the existing momentum and supports the large LPE recruitment at the back end of FY17. Closing net cash of £71.3m provides
sufficient balance sheet capacity to fund the US launch and increased marketing spend across the existing markets.

UK Reaches Point of Inflection — The UK business has reached a point of inflection, achieving a maiden EBITDA positive result of £1.7m and delivering implied volume transaction of c.41,700. Purplebricks has announced the additional marketing spend in the UK of £3.5m in the first half to leverage its momentum across the business. Purplebricks estimate online market share of 72%, up from 62%. We see the result as a validation of the underlying business model.

Australia Continues to Show Early Signs of Momentum — Australia continues to track ahead of the UK at the same time of development on almost all metrics. Revenues for the 8 months of trading came in at £3.5m (Citi: £3.3m). Purplebricks have guided to £12m revenue in FY18e, unchanged from their previous expectations. We anticipate Australia to be EBITDA positive in FY19e.

US Update — Limited additional US details are provided following the announcement of California as the initial launch site this month.

n Implications — The strong FY18e revenue guidance is +21% ahead of consensus and therefore we expect material upgrades to consensus estimates. Our Buy rating
reflects the upside as Purplebricks revolutionizes the industry and expands internationally, particularly as the maiden EBITDA positive result for the UK business validates the business model.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Purplebricks is not, in our view, a shy and retiring company, until it comes to disclosing how many homes it sells. However, whilst we do not know the number of homes it has helped sell, a key performance indicator in our mind, we do know that it delivered losses of £6m in FY2017 against our estimate of a £4m loss. We hope that at the results presentation we can coax the company to reveal the number of homes it has helped to sell.

BE12:01pm

The messaging in the statement seems a bit confused to us, on the one hand they 'have built a growing brand awareness' and yet 'UK marketing spend in the first half of this financial year is now expected to increase by some £3.5m year on year with spend in the second half also likely to rise'. Marketing spend in FY16 was £12.9m rising to £18.2m in FY17 and it will start with a '2' in FY18. The digital model may not have to fund a branch network, but it appears to us that the virtual high street is not as cheap as one might imagine.
